title: Valuing the Softer Side of Business Education
sub_head: It pays to know your customers.
body:
In “Should Aspiring Entrepreneurs Major in Business?” (Journal Report, Nov. 4), John Sullivan suggests that business founders need specific skills. As a business owner, I agree. But I disagree that a college business program necessarily provides those skills.
Henry Doss, who takes the other side in the debate, is closer to reality. The skills business owners need lie in critical thinking, communication and “insight into the human condition.” I was a communication major. I learned more about business in my public-relations class than in business electives. We learned to create audience profiles, similar to customer or client profiles. We learned to ask “what’s the situation?” about a given issue. In business, we need to find the problems our customers have and provide solutions. The parallels run deeper than I have space to write.
